required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Dual-mobility vs. Single-bearing Components in THA at "High Risk" for Prosthetic Dislocation

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare clinical outcomes of patients considered to be high risk for prosthetic dislocation undergoing primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) with the use of a dual mobility bearing versus a conventional, single bearing design.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare clinical outcomes of patients considered to be high risk for prosthetic dislocation undergoing primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) with the use of a dual mobility bearing versus a conventional, single bearing design.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Randomized controlled trial with two groups: THA with dual mobility components vs THA with single-bearing designs.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 6 weeks following their index surgical procedure.
primary_outcome.description: The rate of prosthetic dislocation between the two cohorts

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 year following their index surgical procedure.
primary_outcome.description: The rate of prosthetic dislocation between the two cohorts

primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 years following their index surgical procedure.
primary_outcome.description: The rate of prosthetic dislocation between the two cohorts

primary_outcome.time_frame: 5 years following their index surgical procedure.
primary_outcome.description: The rate of prosthetic dislocation between the two cohorts

primary_outcome.time_frame: 10 years following their index surgical procedure.
primary_outcome.description: The rate of prosthetic dislocation between the two cohorts

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Complications will be assess up to 10 years following their index surgical procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Any peri- or postoperative complications will be recorded component loosening, occurrence of intraprosthetic dislocation, infection, periprosthetic fractures, revision rates

secondary_outcome.measure: Radiographic signs of loosening and proper component placement.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 weeks following their index surgical procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Routine radiographs (AP Pelvis, frogleg lateral, and cross-table lateral radiographs) will be obtained at follow-up visits and assessed for cup placement, anteversion, radiographic signs of loosening, and component migration. These radiographs will be assess for the presence of loosening in a yes/no format

secondary_outcome.measure: Radiographic signs of loosening and proper component placement.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 year following their index surgical procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Routine radiographs (AP Pelvis, frogleg lateral, and cross-table lateral radiographs) will be obtained at follow-up visits and assessed for cup placement, anteversion, radiographic signs of loosening, and component migration. These radiographs will be assess for the presence of loosening in a yes/no format

arm_group.description: Patients in this group will receive a dual mobility hip implant
Patients in this group will receive a traditional, single-bearing hip implant.

intervention.description: Patients that are eligible and consent to the study will be randomized to receive either a dual mobility implant or a traditional single-bearing hip implant. This group is for the dual mobility implant

Patients that are eligible and consent to the study will be randomized to receive either a dual mobility implant or a traditional single-bearing hip implant. This group is for the dual mobility implant

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Primary THA for a diagnosis of osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis in the setting of a history of prior lumbar or lumbosacral fusion performed at least 6 months prior to their THA. In addition, patients considered high-risk for potential prosthetic dislocation will be included based on the presence of one or more of the following: neuromuscular disorder (e.g. cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, history of a stroke), dementia or cognitive impairment, substance or alcohol abuse (>10 drinks per week), acute displaced femoral neck fracture, age > 75 years, inflammatory arthritis, and increased preoperative range of motion (calculated as described by Krenzel et al.: combined flexion, adduction, internal rotation > 115 degrees).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Less than 18 years of age
- Revision THA
- spinopelvic fusion that is more recent than 6 months prior to THA
- isolated cervical or thoracic fusion
- intent to undergo a revision spinopelvic fusion within one year of their index THA
- a history of prior infection in the affected hip
- a history of prior open surgery on the affected hip (i.e. prior proximal femur fracture or osteotomy)
- or a preoperative diagnosis of post-traumatic arthritis, avascular necrosis, or fracture
